hey, welcome to 12tone! back in the day, when
I was a younger, less experienced theorist,

I used to spend a lot of time browsing Wikipedia's
list of musical scales. it's a great page:

it's where I learned about things like the
enigmatic scale, the prometheus scale, and
the bebop scales, among others.

it was a fun resource for quickly learning
about all sorts of different musical ideas,

but one day, while browsing through it, I
stumbled on a scale completely unlike anything

I'd ever seen before, a scale that challenged
some of the most basic assumptions I had about
how music worked: The Bohlen-Pierce Scale.

honestly, it was intimidating, and while I
did some additional research I still couldn't

so… what made it so weird?

well, let's start from the beginning: the
Bohlen-Pierce scale was discovered independently

at least three times in the 70s and 80s, first
by German microwave engineer Heinz Bohlen,

then by Dutch theorist Kees Van Prooijen,
and finally by another microwave engineer,

American John Robinson Pierce, who, after
learning of Bohlen's work, gave it its current
name.

each of them used a different approach to
find the scale, but for the purposes of this

video I'll be sticking with the model that
I think is the simplest.

basically, at the heart of the Bohlen-Pierce
Scale is a question about consonance.

specifically, what makes the major triad sound
good?

while the answer depends a lot on what kind
of theorist you're asking, and I can and will

probably do a whole video about it at some
point, one widely accepted explanation is

that the major triad sounds good because the
intervals between its notes are fairly simple.

you see, when you hear a note, what you're
really hearing is a sound wave with a specific

frequency, and when you hear multiple notes
at once your ear effectively calculates the

ratios between those frequencies, which is
what we call an interval. in the case of the

major triad, the three notes approximate the
ratio 4:5:6, which is about as small as you

can get, so compared to most other collections
of three notes, the major triad is easy to
process and, thus, pleasant.

now, if 4:5:6 is consonant, we might expect
similar behavior from other simple ratios.

like, let's spread this out a bit and look
at 3:5:7. we don't usually use a lot of 7-based

ratios, but on average these numbers are roughly
equivalent to the major triad, so at first

glance it seems like it should probably be
about the same level of consonance, right?

well… not quite, because of a pesky little
thing called octave equivalency.

you see, technically speaking, an octave is
a doubling in frequency, and notes an octave

apart sound so similar that traditional western
music treats them as effectively two different
versions of the same thing.

and it's not just western music: basically
every musical culture I'm aware of does something
similar.

I'm always hesitant to describe anything in
music as universal, but as far as I can tell,

the concept of octave equivalency is pretty
close.

I'm no ethnomusicologist, though, so take
that with a grain of salt, and if you do know

of any counterexamples, please let me know
in the comments.

anyway, the reason this is a problem is that
the 3:5:7 ratio is wider than an octave, so

if we want to examine it in its most compact
form, we have to double that three, giving
us 5:6:7 instead.

this is a kind of diminished triad, and it's
generally considered dissonant.

now, a normal person might look at this result
and think "well, looks like we're wrong",
but we're not gonna do that.

instead, let's consider the possibility that
we're right, and the entire history of western

music and most other musical traditions are
wrong instead.
that seems like a fair assumption, right?
great.

but getting rid of octave equivalency comes
with a cost, 'cause the octave serves a really

important purpose in traditional scales: it
provides a point of repetition.

like, if I want to define the C major scale,
I just have to fill in the first 8 notes (bang)

and then tell you that, after this C here,
it does the same thing all over again, so

the fact that it has this E means it has all
the other Es as well.

but if the octave is gone, we can't do that:
we have to define each individual note across

the entire frequency spectrum, which sounds
exhausting, so instead let's just introduce
a new point of repetition.

we're trying to fit the interval 3:7, and
the simplest ratio that's bigger than that

is 1:3, often called a tritave, so let's just
use that.

quick sidenote on terminology: "octave" comes
from the latin "octo", meaning 8, because

most traditional Western scales use 7 distinct
pitches, making the octave the 8th note.

"tritave", on the other hand, comes from "tri",
meaning 3, and while I get that it's meant

as a reference to the 1:3 ratio, that implies
that an octave is a 1:8 ratio, which it very

much isn't. if we wanted to be consistent,
we should really be using Bohlen's suggestion

of Decade, since as we'll see later on most
of the scales built with it use 9 distinct

pitches, but sadly, no one asked my opinion
before deciding which name to use, probably

because I hadn't been born yet, and Pierce's
suggestion of Tritave seems to have won out
even though it makes less sense.

I'll be using it in this video 'cause it's
the most common name, but that doesn't mean
I have to like it.

anyway, now that we have our boundaries, let's
build a scale.

we'll start with a tritave: (bang) and from
here, we'll build one of our 3:5:7 chords

based on the root. then, to fill it out a
bit, we'll add another one hanging down from

the tritave: (bang) this is starting to look
like a real scale, but it's still pretty sparse,

so to fill it in a bit more, let's look at
these three notes.

just like the last chord, they hang down from
the tritave, but they form a different ratio,

5:7:9. this gives us a new kind of chord to
work with, and since we found it hanging down

from the tritave, it seems only fair that
we build another one coming up from the root.

that gives us this: (bang) and now our scale
is really starting to take shape.

it's still got some pretty big gaps, though:
we've got seven notes, just like normal, but

since they're covering a larger area they've
kind of drifted apart.

if we look at those gaps, we see they come
in three main sizes: we have small ones, medium
ones, and big ones.

or, ok, technically there's two slightly different
kinds of small ones, but we're gonna pretend
there isn't 'cause I'm lazy.
don't worry, we'll circle back to that eventually.

the point, though, is that, by sheer luck,
these three gap sizes are pretty close to

a ratio of 1:2:3, which means the medium ones
are basically just two small ones, and the
big ones are a small and a medium.

this makes them kind of analogous to half-steps,
whole steps, and minor 3rds, so we can just

fill those large gaps with the medium intervals
and bam: (bang) we've got a complete Bohlen-Pierce
scale.

it's not the only one, because that would
be way too easy, but it's called Lambda, and
it's one of the most common.
relatively speaking.

brief sidenote on notation: because basic
Bohlen-Pierce scales use 9 notes instead of

7, we have to add two more note names if we
want nice, pretty-looking scales. we're already

using A through G, so the logical approach
is to add the next two letters of the alphabet,

H and I. however, I is a bit of a problem
because it's often used as a roman numeral

to represent the I chord, so we skip it and
use J instead.

for staff notation, middle C stays exactly
where it is but those two extra notes push

everything else around, so it can be kind
of hard to read if you're not used to it,

but don't worry, you'll probably never have
to sightread any Bohlen-Pierce music.
hopefully.

anyway, now that we have Lambda we can write
music with it, but those medium gaps are still
bugging me.

I mean, what if we want to use notes from
outside the scale? shouldn't we fill those

in just in case? well, yes, we probably should,
and we can do that by turning each medium

step into two small steps, which gives us
the full, chromatic Bohlen-Pierce Scale: (bang)

this has a new problem, though: remember how
I said we had two different kinds of small
steps?
well now we have four, which is just silly.

it turns out the medium step didn't divide
quite as evenly as we'd hoped, but that's
ok: we can fix it.

we just have to borrow some inspiration from
standard tuning.

you see, up to now we've been doing what's
called just intonation, which is where you

build your intervals based on the precise
frequency ratio you want.

western music used to do that, but the human
ear is actually pretty good at rounding, so

a couple hundred years ago we started shifting
to what's called equal temperament instead.

here, we sacrifice a little bit of that precision
in exchange for making all our half-steps
be the same distance.

this makes things more consistent, allowing
you to play the same thing in any key you

want, and the intervals are still close enough
that it doesn't really bother most listeners.

and we can do the same thing to Bohlen-Pierce:
we've got 13 steps to the tritave, so what

happens if, instead of distributing them based
on these complex frequency calculations, we
just spread them out as evenly as possible?

well, then we get this: (bang) which, lucky
for us, is pretty close to what we had before.

in fact, on average, the equal-tempered Bohlen-Pierce
scale is actually better than 12-tone equal

temperament at approximating its intended
ratios.

each step is about halfway between a half-step
and a whole step in standard tuning, so the

notes are a bit further apart than we're used
to but they're still small enough to feel
like, well, steps.

this equal-tempered version is generally considered
the default these days, but some folks still

use just intonation too, so if you like that
one better that's still an option.

but either way, probably the most exciting
thing about Bohlen-Pierce is the chords: in

standard tuning, the two main triads are major
and minor, both of which are the same size.

that is, the distance from the root to the
highest note is the same in both cases: the
only difference is the note in the middle.

but in Bohlen-Pierce, the two main triads
are actually primarily distinguished by size:

there's the 3:5:7 one we started with, called
the wide triad, and the 5:7:9 one we found

later, called the narrow triad. and because
of that, there's a lot more chord options

in any given scale: Lambda, for instance has
6 of each of these triads, for a total of

12, compared to major's 7. in fact, Bohlen,
Van Prooijen, and Pierce all argued to some

extent that this could be fertile ground for
a new concept of tonality, one that behaved

similarly to traditional western harmony but
with completely different building blocks.

there is one slight problem with that, though:
inversions.

basically, in standard tuning, we can identify
chords as similar even if the notes aren't

in the same order, so this: (bang) and this:
(bang) both register as C major.

this is because of our old pal octave equivalency:
we took this C and moved it up an octave,

but we still hear that as just another C.
on the other hand, if I play you this Bohlen-Pierce

chord: (bang) and then raise the bottom note
up a tritave, you get this: (bang) which most

people would rate as a related but fundamentally
different chord. we don't seem to have a natural

instinct for tritave equivalency, which makes
it hard to do full band arrangements because

different instruments in different registers
don't sound like they're playing the same
notes.

in fact, the two chords we've been using,
the wide one and the narrow one, are actually

just inversions of each other, at least in
a tritave-based system, and I bet you didn't
even notice.

some Bohlen-Pierce advocates argue, though,
that this may be a matter of enculturation:

we recognize octaves as equivalent not because
they are, at least not in any objective sense,

but because we're used to music that treats
them like they are so we learn to assume it.

if that's true, it's possible that listeners
raised on Bohlen-Pierce music could learn

tritave equivalency just as easily as we did
octaves.
but is it true? well…

Pierce did some studies, along with his collaborator
Max Matthews, indicating that people with

musical training identify inversions more
strongly than people without, so it's probably

at least partly learned, but on the other
hand, again, basically every culture I'm aware

of has some concept that we'd recognize as
octave equivalency, which probably isn't a
coincidence.

I'm not a psychologist, though, so for now
I'm just gonna say… maybe? but at the very

least, they're definitely right that you can
make some pretty cool-sounding music with

it, so if you want to check it out I've linked
to an Elaine Walker piece called Stick Men
in the description.

and there we have it: something partway between
a scale and a tuning system, based on intervals

we don't normally use, with no octaves, chords
measured not by quality but by size, and inversions

that might or might not exist, depending on
whether or not octaves are real.

it's a lot to take in, and it was definitely
pretty intimidating for me back when I first

started reading about it, but hopefully this
helped demystify it a bit, or at least helped

explain why it's so mystifying in the first
place.

it may not be the hardest thing I've ever
learned, but the Bohlen-Pierce Scale will

always hold a special place in my heart as
the first theory concept I ever truly, deeply

did not understand, and I gotta say: it feels
good to finally beat it.
